verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Israel who came to Egypt with Jacob, each with his household:
verses.comment: Opening listing echoes Genesis 46. Intentionally preserves 'Israel' as Jacob’s name.

verses.text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah,
verses.comment: Names retained as transliterated.

verses.text: Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,
verses.comment: Retains traditional names as per Hebrew.

verses.text: Dan and Naphtali, Gad and Asher.
verses.comment: Same family order as Genesis 35. No change.

verses.text: All the descendants of Jacob were seventy people. Joseph was already in Egypt.
verses.comment: Hebrew literally, “all the souls.” Rendered as ‘descendants’ for clarity.

verses.text: Then Joseph died, and all his brothers and all that generation.
verses.comment: “Generation” translates Hebrew ‘dor’, meaning age/group of people.

verses.text: But the sons of Israel were fruitful and greatly multiplied. They grew so numerous and became very strong, so that the land was filled with them.
verses.comment: Hebrew uses multiple verbs for 'increase,' retained for emphasis.

verses.text: Now a new king arose over Egypt who did not know Joseph.
verses.comment: ‘Arose’ for the Hebrew verb. Doesn't know = not familiar or not favorable.

verses.text: He said to his people, “Behold, the people of the sons of Israel are more numerous and stronger than we are.
verses.comment: ‘Sons of Israel’ closely follows Hebrew. ‘Behold’ is retained for direct address.

verses.text: Come, let us deal shrewdly with them, so they do not multiply further, and if war breaks out, they might join our enemies and fight against us and escape from the land.”
verses.comment: ‘Deal shrewdly’ is literal. ‘Escape from the land’ preserves ambiguity of Heb. word.

verses.text: Therefore they set taskmasters over them to oppress them with forced labor. And they built for Pharaoh the store cities, Pithom and Raamses.
verses.comment: ‘Taskmasters’ is literal. ‘Store cities’ translates for Heb. 'miskenot.'

verses.text: But the more they oppressed them, the more they multiplied and spread, so that the Egyptians were afraid of the sons of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Multiplied and spread’ directly follows doubling of Heb. verbs.

verses.text: So the Egyptians made the sons of Israel serve ruthlessly.
verses.comment: ‘Serve ruthlessly’ is a close rendering of Hebrew for harsh bondage.

verses.text: They made their lives bitter with hard labor in mortar and brick, and with all kinds of work in the field. All their labor which they forced on them was ruthless.
verses.comment: Retains list of duties as in Hebrew. Emphasis on bitter suffering.

verses.text: Then the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives, one of whom was named Shiphrah and the other Puah.
verses.comment: Names transliterated from Hebrew. ‘Midwives’ matches context.

verses.text: He said, “When you serve as midwife to the Hebrew women and see them on the birth stool, if it is a son, you shall kill him; but if it is a daughter, she shall live.”
verses.comment: ‘Birth stool’ translates Hebrew ‘oven stones’ (likely a birthing seat).

verses.text: But the midwives feared God and did not do as the king of Egypt commanded them, but let the boys live.
verses.comment: ‘Feared God’ preserves Hebrew emphasis on piety.

verses.text: So the king of Egypt called the midwives and said to them, “Why have you done this, and let the boys live?”
verses.comment: Formal accusation is retained; matches legal tone.

verses.text: The midwives answered Pharaoh, “Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women, for they are vigorous and give birth before the midwife comes to them.”
verses.comment: ‘Vigorous’ chosen for Heb. ‘chayot,’ lit. “lively.”

verses.text: So God dealt well with the midwives, and the people multiplied and grew very strong.
verses.comment: ‘Dealt well’ follows Hebrew ‘made good to.’

verses.text: And because the midwives feared God, He gave them families of their own.
verses.comment: ‘Families of their own’ for Heb. ‘houses’ (social status), clarified for modern readers.

verses.text: Then Pharaoh commanded all his people, saying, “Every son who is born to the Hebrews you shall throw into the Nile, but every daughter you shall let live.”
verses.comment: ‘Throw into the Nile’ is literal; keeps horrific force of decree.
